description: The heraldic sense “leaping” and the sense “projecting outward” are borrowed from Latin salientem, the accusative form of saliēns (“springing, leaping”), present participle of saliō (“leap, spring”, verb). The senses “prominent” and “pertinent” are relatively recent, and derive from the phrase salient point, which is a calque of the Latin punctum saliēns, a translation of Aristotle's term for the embryonal heart visible in (opened) eggs, which he thought seemed to move already. Compare also the German calque der springende Punkt.

adjectives.description: salient (comparative more salient, superlative most salient)

entries.meaning: Worthy of note; pertinent or relevant.
examples: Synonyms: pertinent, relevant; see also Thesaurus:pertinent
The article is not exhaustive, but it covers the salient points pretty well.

entries.meaning: (heraldry, usually of a quadruped) Depicted in a leaping posture.
(obsolete) Moving by leaps or springs; jumping.
(geometry) Denoting any angle less than two right angles.
(military) An outwardly projecting part of a fortification, trench system, or line of defense.
(geography) An elongated protrusion of a geopolitical entity, such as a subnational entity or a sovereign state.
